sections.title: Broken, chipped or cracked teeth
sections.body:
If you’ve chipped a tooth, cracked a corner, or something feels sharp or painful, it’s worth getting it checked promptly.

Some problems look small but involve deeper cracks or exposed dentine, which can lead to sensitivity, infection, or a larger fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain what we can see, and recommend the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable.
bullets: Quick smoothing to prevent cuts to cheeks or tongue

sections.body:
Teeth can chip or crack for lots of reasons — biting something hard, an old filling giving way, grinding, or an accident.

Sometimes it’s mainly cosmetic. Sometimes it’s an early warning that the tooth is under stress.

If you’re unsure, we’d rather you call and ask. We can advise whether it sounds urgent and what to do in the meantime.

sections.title: Common signs
items: A sharp edge that catches your tongue or floss
Pain on biting or when you release the bite
Sensitivity to cold, sweet foods, or air
A visible crack, chip, or missing corner/filling
Swelling, a bad taste, or persistent throbbing pain

sections.title: What to do now
items: Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods
Keep the area clean with gentle brushing and warm salt-water rinses
If a sharp edge is cutting you, cover it temporarily with sugar-free gum or dental wax
Use your normal pain relief if needed and safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Call us so we can advise timing and book the right appointment

sections.label: Protect the tooth
sections.title: Why it’s worth checking
sections.body:
A chip or crack isn’t always an emergency, but it can change quickly.

Small fractures can spread, and exposed dentine can become very sensitive. In some cases, cracks allow bacteria to reach the nerve, leading to infection.

Seeing you early gives us more conservative options — and helps prevent the problem turning into a bigger repair.

sections.label: What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.body:
Treatment depends on where the crack is, how deep it goes, and how much tooth is missing.

Options may include smoothing a sharp edge, a bonded repair (composite), replacing or reshaping an old filling, or protecting the tooth with an onlay or crown.

If the nerve is involved, root canal treatment may be needed — but we only recommend that when it’s clearly indicated.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.body: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can a chipped tooth wait?
faqs.answer: Sometimes a small chip can wait a short time, but it’s best to get advice. Chips can expose dentine, increase sensitivity, or develop into a larger fracture. Call us and we’ll guide you on timing.

faqs.question: Will I need a crown straight away?
faqs.answer: Not always. We usually start with the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable. That may be smoothing, a bonded repair, or replacing a filling. A crown or onlay is recommended when the tooth needs extra protection.

faqs.question: Is it safe to keep eating?
faqs.answer: Try to avoid chewing on the affected side until we’ve assessed the tooth. Softer foods and careful cleaning help. If biting triggers sharp pain, stop and contact us as that can suggest a deeper crack.

sections.title: Book care for a chipped or cracked tooth
sections.body: We will protect the tooth, relieve sensitivity, and plan the right repair.

clinical_focus: Full-coverage restorations for cracked and heavily restored teeth
Scan-guided margin and occlusion design for predictable fit
typical_case_type: Posterior teeth following root canal therapy needing reinforcement
Fractured cusps or extensive failing restorations requiring coverage
planning_considerations: Crack mapping, remaining dentine thickness, and parafunctional risk
Material selection matched to aesthetic zone and occlusal load
Bite protection planning, including splinting where indicated
